name: 6-[2-(1-benzyl-3,3-dimethyl-1,3-dihydro-2H-indol-2-ylidene)ethylidene]-4-bromo-2-nitrocyclohexa-2,4-dien-1-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2344
Reason:
To predict the melting point of 6-[2-(1-benzyl-3,3-dimethyl-1,3-dihydro-2H-indol-2-ylidene)ethylidene]-4-bromo-2-nitrocyclohexa-2,4-dien-1-one, we can start with the basic unit of benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. We then consider the impact of various functional groups and structural features present in our target compound relative to benzene:
- Bromine substituent: +40 (heavy atom with significant van der Waals forces)
- Nitro group: +80 (introduces polarity and possible intermolecular hydrogen bonding)
- Two aromatic rings additional to benzene: +40 (increment per ring due to pi-stacking and increased molecular size)
- Keto group (cyclohexadienone): +20 (polarity)
- Benzyl group: +20 (additional phenyl and alkyl chain)
- Two methyl groups and one tertiary carbon in the indole structure: +10 (steric bulk)
- Conjugation and rigidity in the structure: +30 (conjugated and planar structures tend to have higher melting points)

These adjustments are not additive but these figures give us a rough estimate of the effects of the functional groups. We combine these to get an estimated melting point adjustment from the base benzene unit.
Test (Predicted reason):
The target compound has several functional groups that influence its melting point: 
- Benzene ring: +80 (base value for aromatic compounds)
- Indole ring: +40 (due to the presence of nitrogen and aromaticity)
- Bromine atom: +50 (due to its large size and high electronegativity, which increases intermolecular forces)
- Nitro group: +30 (due to its strong electron-withdrawing nature and potential for hydrogen bonding)
- Cyclohexadienone structure: +20 (due to the rigidity and planarity of the structure, which can lead to better packing)
- Two ethylidene groups: +10 each (due to the increase in molecular weight and van der Waals forces)

Adding these values together gives us a predicted melting point.
##Prediction: 200.0
